message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that causes DNA damage and cell death. Among the options, only lomustine is also an alkylating agent that works in a similar way to busulfan. Vemurafenib is a kinase inhibitor, etoposide is a topoisomerase inhibitor, and cytarabine is a nucleoside analog.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that works by damaging DNA. Lomustine is also an alkylating agent that works by damaging DNA, making it the most similar in mechanism of action among the options. Vemurafenib is a BRAF inhibitor used to treat melanoma, Etoposide is a topoisomerase inhibitor used to treat various types of cancer, and Cytarabine is a cytidine analog used to treat leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that damages DNA and prevents cancer cells from dividing. Among the options, Lomustine also belongs to the alkylating agent class and works in a similar way. Vemurafenib inhibits a specific protein involved in cancer cell growth and is used to treat melanoma. Etoposide and Cytarabine are not alkylating agents and have different mechanisms of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that crosslinks DNA strands to prevent cell division. Lomustine is also an alkylating agent with a similar mechanism of action. Etoposide is a topoisomerase II inhibitor that prevents DNA from uncoiling, while Cytarabine is a cytidine analogue that inhibits DNA synthesis. Vemurafenib is a BRAF inhibitor used to treat melanomas with a specific mutation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan is an alkylating agent and cross-links DNA strands, preventing normal DNA replication and transcription. Lomustine also has this mechanism of action, making it the drug that acts most similarly to busulfan. The other options, Vemurafenib, Etoposide, and Cytarabine, have different mechanisms of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that is used to treat multiple myeloma by damaging DNA in fast-growing cells, including cancer cells. Among the options, only Lomustine is also an alkylating agent that works by a similar mechanism of action. Vemurafenib is a BRAF inhibitor used to treat melanoma, etoposide is a topoisomerase inhibitor used to treat various types of cancer, and cytarabine is a nucleoside analog used to treat leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that works by crosslinking DNA strands and preventing cell division. Lomustine also works via the same mechanism and is used for the treatment of brain tumors and Hodgkin's lymphoma. None of the other options have similar mechanisms of action. Vemurafenib is a BRAF inhibitor used for the treatment of melanoma, and etoposide and cytarabine are chemotherapy drugs used in the treatment of various cancers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan works by damaging the DNA of cancer cells, and Lomustine also works by damaging the DNA of cancer cells, making it the drug that acts via a similar mechanism of action. The other options work via different mechanisms. Vemurafenib is a kinase inhibitor, Etoposide works by inhibiting topoisomerase II, and Cytarabine works by inhibiting DNA polymerase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan is an alkylating agent used in chemotherapy, which works by binding to DNA and causing cell death. Lomustine also works by alkylating DNA and is used in the treatment of brain tumors. Vemurafenib, Etoposide, and Cytarabine work through different mechanisms and are not similar in action to busulfan.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that crosslinks DNA, and among the options, only Lomustine works in a similar way. Vemurafenib is a BRAF inhibitor, Etoposide is a topoisomerase inhibitor, and Cytarabine is an antimetabolite.
